image.altText: A man puts a canister of nitrous oxide on the ground.

props.synopsis: At first glance, it would be easy to mistake for an Uber Eats delivery. The driver isn't here to drop off food, though — it's a 3.3 litre canister of nitrous oxide.

title.children: Nitrous oxide has been linked to paralysis and death. We got it delivered to our door

image.altText: A group of women in different shapes and sizes cook together in a neighbourhood house.

props.synopsis: As household budgets are tightened due to increased costs of living, these community-run cooking classes show how it's possible to eat healthily without spending a fortune.

title.children: Community cooking classes are helping make healthy eating more affordable

image.altText: A woman with a bouffant chats to a blonde woman in a pale blue evening gown

props.synopsis: When Diana was 15, her father secretly married a glamorous, younger woman. The future princess and her stepmother became locked in a bitter rivalry. But it ended with a surprise friendship.

title.children: 'She is the mother I never had': How Diana's worst enemy became her closest confidante

image.altText: A woman wearing a sari holds up a photo of a man wearing a white shirt and red and yellow scarf.

props.synopsis: A candidate in India’s elections has been mired in scandal since almost 3,000 videos of him allegedly sexually assaulting multiple women began circulating. Here's how the issue has sparked a national conversation about the treatment of women.

title.children: The grandson of a former PM was running for election. Then a USB drive with shocking content was found

image.altText: A composite image of Eurovision performers from Switzerland, Israel and Croatia.

props.synopsis: A controversial Eurovision has come to an end with the winner crowned, earning the winning country its first top honour in more than three decades.

title.children: The highs and lows of Eurovision song contest in Sweden as winner crowned

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Still trying to convince people you can beat my quiz? Let's see if you can.

title.children: Always said you'd smash Hard Quiz? I'll believe it when I see it … Let's play, HARD!

image.altText: Veronika Gobba in a dark shirt, holding a pink takeaway coffee cup and a stack of textbooks.

props.synopsis: Drowning in HECS debt amid a housing affordability crisis, students are choosing frozen yoghurts and bubble teas to pep themselves up when saving feels futile.

title.children: As HECS debts and house prices rise, students turn to 'little treats' to get them through

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands in front of a vibrant red tree.

props.synopsis: Further energy bill relief is firming as a likely feature in Treasurer Jim Chalmers's third budget, as the government seeks to reassure Australians it will do more to tackle rising living costs.

title.children: Middle-income Australians, families and pensioners to receive boosts in budget says Chalmers

image.altText: White glowing rectangular and circular pullouts on top of photograph of Archie Moore sitting with his artwork kith and kin.

props.synopsis: It took four people months to draw Archie Moore's enormous family tree – but it'll all be erased soon.

title.children: This hand-drawn family tree stretches 60 metres and 65,000 years — and tells a story about us all

image.altText: A woman is silouhetted from behind, her hair windblow, as she looks into a bright pink and purple sky.

props.synopsis: I fled intimate partner violence. Here's my advice for what to say to support someone going through the same thing.

title.children: I once left an abusive relationship — here's what you should say to someone in that situation

image.altText: Grief educator Rebecca Feinglos, who has thick brunette hair, poses for a photo in a garden setting wearing a fawn coloured top

props.synopsis: For many of us, Mother's Day is a time when our hearts are a bit sore. I miss my own mother so much. I miss her humour, her levity, her wisdom, and the way she made everything seem better. So how should we think about this day when grief is still fresh?

title.children: If the Hallmark version of Mother's Day feels like a punch in the gut, you're not alone

image.altText: A man in a suit leaves an apartment.

props.synopsis: Rishi Sunak has been hit with crippling blows at council elections in the UK but as the country potentially turns to Labor, he is increasingly turning towards a past Australian solution to cling to power.

title.children: The UK PM is banking on a Tony Abbott-like plan to win re-election

image.altText: Bank of big fans stacked on top of each other

props.synopsis: Sucking carbon dioxide directly out of the air and burying underground is touted as a crucial way to avoid the worst of global warming. So how does it work, and is it for real?

title.children: In Iceland, a giant vacuum hoovers up carbon. Is it a solution to global warming, or a dangerous distraction?

image.altText: Two divers in a large body of clear blue water illuminated by a torch light.

props.synopsis: Graham Kilsby turned the sinkhole on his family's farming property into a tourism attraction to cover insurance. Now it's attracting visitors from interstate and overseas.

title.children: The rise of sinkhole tourism sees Limestone Coast become international drawcard

image.altText: Exterior of a suburban medical clinic.

props.synopsis: An after-hours GP clinic in Hobart's northern suburbs will close at the end of the month. It follows announcements that two other southern Tasmanian clinics are closing, and comes at a time of increasing pressure on hospital emergency departments.

title.children: Another after-hours GP practice in Hobart announces closure

image.altText: A middle aged bald white man standing on a country road in front of a parked motorbike.

props.synopsis: Trying to get an appointment with a psychologist or psychiatrist can be a battle, but for people in regional Australia it can be almost impossible. They say the lack of services is dangerous and are desperate for more support.

title.children: Australia's mental health crisis is no secret — but people in the bush are dying

image.altText: Courtroom sketch of Donald Trump. He is in the centre of the frame with a flash of yellow hair standing out in a purple scene.

props.synopsis: From "surfboard eyebrows" to an "incredible coiffe", veteran courtroom sketch artist Christine Cornell explains how she captures the features and the feelings of Donald Trump's hush money trial.

title.children: Meet the artist behind the viral courtroom sketches of Donald Trump

image.altText: Bill Mohana owner Hair Royale Westfields Bondi Junction

props.synopsis: Monday marks one month since the deadly stabbing attack at Westfield Bondi Junction which left six people dead, as the community works through the painful process of "reclaiming" the space.

title.children: 'How do you get past it?' One month on, Bill's clients still want to talk about Bondi Junction attack

image.altText: Four people - two men and two women - sit at a desk in suits and dresses, facing a panel of people.

props.synopsis: Housekeeping for Beginners is set in a queer home in North Macedonia, but it started in Melbourne.

title.children: A gay man and woman get married to circumvent homophobic parenting laws in this Aussie-Macedonian film

image.altText: Nathan Cleary runs with the ball

props.synopsis: NSW is expected to be without Nathan Cleary for the entire State of Origin series after scans revealed the extent of his hamstring injury.

title.children: Cleary set to miss Blues' State of Origin campaign after tearing hamstring

image.altText: A woman opens a small wooden box on a table.

props.synopsis: A Melbourne woman found a real human skeleton in her garage and was left wondering what to do. It has led experts to call for clearer guidelines around how to relinquish them.

title.children: A real human skeleton sat in Edna's garage for decades, but when she wanted to dispose of it, she didn't know what to do

image.altText: A white tent set up behind police tape in a park.

props.synopsis: A homicide investigation is underway after a man was found dead just past midnight in Brisbane's south, with locals showing up to the sporting grounds this morning for a special Mother's Day soccer game.

title.children: Locals scared by 'devastating' news of overnight murder

image.altText: Two men look off camera, with trees in the background.

props.synopsis: Many people deported to Tonga arrive with few connections to the country — a trend experts say is fuelling the country's drug problem. But a group of returnees are using their own experiences to help others find their feet in the Pacific country.

title.children: These returnees to Tonga arrived as strangers to their own land — now they're helping fight a drug crisis

image.altText: Ninette Simons with severe facial bruising some days after the attack.

props.synopsis: Another man charged over the alleged bashing of a Perth woman during a violent home invasion is a former immigration detainee released into the community while the Coalition was in government in 2020.

title.children: Second man charged over Perth bashing revealed to be former detainee released under Coalition's watch

image.altText: Four men on a three-wheeled motorbike and a trailer, carrying containers and mattresses.

props.synopsis: An estimated 300,000 Palestinians have now left Rafah, as Israel vows to go ahead with its planned offensive in the face off international pressure.

title.children: Tens of thousands of Palestinians evacuate Rafah as aid agencies warn food is running out

image.altText: A person at the beach reapplying sunscreen

props.synopsis: A record-breaking heatwave that swept through parts of Asia has killed dozens of people, shut schools and damaged crops — and although governments have issued practical warnings about heat stroke, experts say the risk of sunburn is less severe.

title.children: As Asia sweats through a heatwave, experts say it's not sunburn you need to worry about

image.altText: A destroyed building with green insulation flying out of the roof area.

props.synopsis: Footage of a powerful tornado that tore through the Western Australian city of Bunbury shows it travelling rapidly as it shreds rooftops and damages homes.

title.children: Footage shows 'frightening' tornado tear off prison roof as city left in chaos

image.altText: A run down, two-storey hotel with crumbling paint.

props.synopsis: When last drinks are called at a town's only pub, it can be a body blow for the community. Sometimes it's the final blow.

title.children: When a country pub closes, it can mean the town is on its last legs

image.altText: Police in Kupang, East Nusa Tenggara speak to a group of Chinese and Indonesian men

props.synopsis: Police in Kupang name seven suspected people smugglers after intercepting a boat carrying Chinese and Indonesian people they believe were headed to Australia.

title.children: Indonesian police name suspected people smugglers after intercepting boat headed to Australia

image.altText: A close-up of an old woman crying while being hugged by another woman.

props.synopsis: Thousands of Ukrainian villagers are evacuated as fierce fighting rages into a second day on the fringes of Ukraine's north-eastern Kharkiv region.

title.children: Evacuations as fierce fighting rages in Ukraine's Kharkiv region, Russia touts gains

image.altText: Rafael Nadal puts his right hand to his face during a match at the Italian Open.

props.synopsis: A second-round defeat has Rafael Nadal considering whether to push for a 15th French Open title at Roland-Garros, while Alex de Minaur wins his opening match in Rome.

title.children: Nadal casts doubt about French Open tilt after Rome exit, de Minaur wins through to next round

image.altText: Ben Hunt prepares to kick the ball with his right foot.

props.synopsis: Ben Hunt and Shane Flanagan refused to get carried away with the Dragons' 28-14 win over the Rabbitohs, noting the side's inconsistency so far this season.

title.children: Dragons offer blunt assessment of their form after beating struggling Rabbitohs

image.altText: A woman holds a bunch of freshly cut flowers while others cut more in the background

props.synopsis: Up to 90 per cent of flowers sold this Mother's Day will be imported as domestic production lags far behind demand.

title.children: Flower farmer's final harvest reveals the challenges of a shrinking industry
